conversation.content:
Case Study:

Career Training is a private registered training organisation (RTO) based in Geraldton, Western Australia. Career Training is recognised as an industry training leader delivering nationally recognised and specialised courses. Registered training organisations (RTOs) are the training providers registered by ASQA (or, in some cases, a state regulator) to deliver nationally recognised vocational education and training (VET) services.

Career Training provides qualifications in various subject areas, including business, community services, information technology and hospitality. There are currently 400 students enrolled across a wide range of courses. There are 35 staff members, including training staff and administration.

The levels of qualifications provided are as follows:

Certificates I, II, III and IV
Diploma
Advanced Diploma
Career Training follows the important standards of the industry and focusses on supporting informed decisions, engagement and participation. The RTO applies a systematic approach to ensure quality across all training and assessment services, including staff and systems. It seeks feedback from students and internal staff every month and conducts internal audits of the company’s policies and procedures to ensure compliance against the standards for registered training organisations.

Mission

Career Training aims to provide the highest quality and research-based vocational business education and facilitate a conducive environment to develop the global mindsets of students

Vision

To become Australia’s leading academy of business and develop well-equipped world’s leaders

Values

Providing a respectful and safe environment for all staff and students.
Integrity, transparency and accountability in work styles.
Fostering an inclusive learning environment for all students
Continuous improvement based on regular feedback from students and the community
Integrating principles of equity and non - discrimination.
Context of the Assessment

Management aims at exploring new marketing opportunities to enhance business growth by promoting courses in Business.

Career Training embraced a review of their present marketing strategies and found various things, including:

The market situation had changed, and the competition had evolved.
The target market characteristics had segmented further with globalisation.
The digital space and media preferences of their market had evolved.
The organisational requirements had become more complicated due to introducing new courses.
Presently, Career training is marketing their courses based on students’ references and word of mouth only. Due to this, marketing outcomes have not been satisfactory. Therefore, Career training is planning to implement new opportunities to promote the business courses.

Strategic objectives for marketing initiatives

To ensure the consistent and positive brand message for the RTO
To increase the enrolments by 10% annually
To promote the new courses through a marketing communication campaign.
To grow brand awareness and market share by 10% by the end of financial year.
Excerpts from the Career Training - Marketing plan (This can be viewed in full on the Career Training Website using the log in details above)

The marketing strategy of Career Training is the annual production and distribution of brochures containing detailed information about courses. There is focus on market penetration and product development. Career training also aims to organise promotional events for students, education agents, and other digital marketing to get more leads and make a brand.

Marketing prospects

Market segmentation
New market development
Promotional events
Upgrading of skills of human resources
Product development
Product diversification
Target audience

Characteristics:

Existing students, students who keep making enquiries of new courses or friends/relatives of existing students.
Students aged 18-25 years
Technology savvy young students


SWOT Analysis Completed:

Strength

• Commitment from stakeholders

• Providing quality training

• Industry contacts

• Experienced management and staff

Weakness

• New RTO

• Not offering a range of qualifications





Opportunities

• A new model for marketing and social media

• Introducing new courses

• Build a relationship across different sector

• To provide quality training

• Adopt new technologies to improve the training

• Global influences

• Market development

Threats

• Changes in the VET sector

• Changes in the Australian political system

• Increased number of RTO providers and competition

• Failure to invest in marketing and advertising appropriately





Marketing mix

Product

Product/services offered are Diploma and Advanced Diploma of Business. The upcoming planned new course, General English-speaking course.

Place

Product/service is intended for college/university students and faculty of Melbourne. It is available face-to-face and via the Internet on any electronic device.

Price

Pricing covers significant costs related to course design, development, resources required and cash flow for future growth.

Promotion

The product/service must be promoted in current and other prospective markets through market development.

The channels will include print media, advertisements and social media platforms

Marketing promotions

Career Training’s marketing promotions program is simplistic, out of date and not yet integrated.

The promotions are limited and predominately traditional. They don’t take into account the rise of social media and social media platforms.

Budget

The management has allocated 5% to 7% of the development budget for marketing opportunities. The development budget is $120,000 (One hundred and twenty thousand dollars)

Task:

The management has appointed you as a new marketing manager.As part of your new role, you called a meeting with relevant staff members to ascertain the key objectives required to move forward with the planned marketing outlines.

The meeting minutes are below including the outcomes and expectations.Use the information to identify the key areas that you, as the Marketing Manager need to focus on and follow the instructions on the assessment requirements. Topics discussed: Discussion on business objectives:The marketing manager presented and target customers and current marketing strategies, Presentation on current market Market trends: product development and trends, potentially new markets and market diversification competitors,Discussion on the marketing opportunities identified. And the following were the discussion held: The marketing manager confirmed the organisational requirements and current strategies, Market trends: product development and market diversification, Potential markets: Other Australian cities through an online course, Competitors: RTO offering a similar course in a specific region and also discussed about * Introduction of new course
* Extend the target market into
* Sydney and Brisbane through online business courses
* Increase the advertising campaign like social media, email marketing
* Upgrade the ability and strength of the organisation by increasing the current quality service standards and upgrading the skills

For each one of the four (4) marketing opportunities that you have identified as being most viable, develop a report that addresses:


Rating of the marketing opportunities and selection of two (2) best opportunities:
Explain why you have chosen the 2 that you have in detail below:

Marketing Opportunity 1: Introducing a new course

Rating: High

Explanation: Introducing a new course can be an excellent marketing opportunity for Career Training. With the introduction of a new course, the organisation can attract more students who are looking for a unique and specialised course. It can also help Career Training to stand out in the market and strengthen its brand image. Moreover, a new course can open doors for collaborations with other institutions and industry partners, thereby increasing opportunities for growth and revenue.

Marketing Opportunity 2: Extending the target market into Sydney and Brisbane through online business courses

Rating: High

Explanation: Career Training can expand its target market by offering online business courses in Sydney and Brisbane. As these cities have a higher population, there is a higher chance of attracting more students. Moreover, online courses can help Career Training reach a broader audience, including working professionals who are unable to enrol in regular face-to-face courses. With online courses, Career Training can also save on infrastructure costs and increase its revenue by offering courses to students outside its local market.

Marketing Opportunity 3: Upgrading the ability and strength of the organisation by increasing the current quality service standards and upgrading the skills

Rating: Medium

Explanation: Upgrading the organisation's service quality standards and upgrading its employees' skills can be a good marketing opportunity as it can help Career Training deliver better quality courses, improve student satisfaction, and attract more students by creating a positive brand image. However, the focus of this opportunity is more on internal improvements rather than direct marketing, which can make it a medium-rated opportunity.

Marketing Opportunity 4: Increasing the advertising campaign like social media, email marketing

Rating: High

Explanation: Increasing advertising campaigns such as social media and email marketing can be a highly effective way of attracting new students and increasing brand awareness. As more people are using social media platforms and checking emails regularly, Career Training can target potential students using these channels. Moreover, social media and email marketing campaigns can be cost-effective compared to traditional advertising methods such as print media, increasing the chances of a higher return on investment. 

Based on the above, the two most viable marketing opportunities for Career Training are Introducing a new course and Extending the target market into Sydney and Brisbane through online business courses. These opportunities can help Career Training to differentiate itself in the market, reach a broader audience, and increase its revenue streams.

Now for the two (2) best opportunities YOU shortlisted .
Using the 2 opportunities, you have researched – you will now do the following with those opportunities:

Plan and coordinate two (2) marketing activities related to these opportunities
1. Outline how you will utilise networks and List networks to be used:, List information sources to be used, What distribution and marketing networks can be utilised to promote these activities.
Apply marketing principles to each activity
2. Outline in detail the marketing management process of the activity: 3. Evaluate and report on the following criteria, for BOTH activities:
a.How did the activities align with the overall marketing direction of the organisation? b.What level of exposure is aiming to be achieved through this marketing activity? c.How will you match the attendees to the target audience? d. Was the activity cost effective overall? Explain.

Marketing Opportunity 1: Introducing a new course

Marketing Activity 1: Social Media Campaign

Utilising Networks: Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, and Twitter.
Information Sources: Career Training Website and various other relevant websites related to business courses.
Distribution and Marketing Networks: Paid advertising, SMM Ads, Digital PR, Influencer Marketing, Community Management.

Marketing Principles:

Segmentation: Targeting students aged 18-25 years, current and prospective students of Career Training.
Product: Highlighting the unique features and benefits of the new course - Advanced Diploma in Entrepreneurship and Innovation.
Promotion: Leveraging social media platforms to create a buzz and awareness about the new course through paid advertising, social media marketing ads, digital PR, influencer marketing, and community management.
Pricing: Offering affordable course fees and promotions for early birds.
Place: Promoting the course on different online platforms, Partner websites, and Career Training website.

Marketing Management Process:

1. Identifying the need for a social media campaign for the launch of the new course - Advanced Diploma in Entrepreneurship and Innovation.
2. Developing a marketing plan with measurable KPIs.
3. Identifying target audiences and their preferences for social media platforms.
4. Creating content calendars and schedules for regular social media posts and targeted ads.
5. Monitoring and evaluating metrics and KPIs to ascertain the effectiveness of the campaign.

Criteria Evaluation:

a. The social media campaign aligns with the overall marketing direction by promoting the organisation's brand image and values, targeting current and prospective students.
b. The aim of the campaign is to achieve maximum exposure on social media platforms for the new course, targeting potential students, and current students looking for a specialised course.
c. The attendees will be matched to the target audience by leveraging data received from the Career Training website and different social media platforms.
d. The activity is cost-effective as it utilises low-cost marketing channels such as social media and influencer marketing, thereby providing a higher return on investment.

Marketing Activity 2: Print Media Advertisements

Utilising Networks: Local Newspapers, Career Training Brochures.
Information Sources: Career Training Website and various relevant websites related to business courses.
Distribution and Marketing Networks: Print Media Platforms, Brochure Distribution at local business events.

Marketing Principles:

Segmentation: Targeting students aged 18-25 years, and those already considering studying at Career Training.
Product: Highlighting the course's features and benefits - Diploma in Business Administration.
Promotion: Leveraging print media platforms such as local newspapers, brochures at local business events, creating awareness and interest.
Pricing: Offering affordable course fees and incentives for early enrolment.
Place: Promoting the course through different print platforms such as newspapers, brochures, and magazines.

Marketing Management Process:

1. Identifying the need for a print media campaign to promote the Diploma in Business Administration course.
2. Developing a marketing plan that includes publishing in various local newspapers, magazines and brochures at local business events.
3. Identifying the target audience by analysing the readership of different publications and location of business events.
4. Designing and developing the print media adverts and brochures
5. Measuring the effectiveness of the campaign through tracking enquiries generated and enrolment rates.

Criteria Evaluation:

a. The print media advertisements align with the overall marketing direction by promoting the organisation's brand image and values, targeting the local community.
b. The aim of the campaign is to create awareness of the course through print media platforms such as newspapers, brochures, and magazines in the local community, leading to enquiries and enrolments.
c. Attendees will be matched with the target audience by identifying the correct placement location for the print media advertisement and brochure distribution site.
d. The activity is cost-effective as it utilises low-cost marketing channels such as print media, thereby providing a higher return on investment.

Overall, both marketing activities align with the overall marketing direction to promote Career Training as a leading provider of specialised business courses. The social media campaign aimed to achieve maximum exposure of the new course, whereas the print media advertisement aimed to create awareness in the local community, generating enquiries leading to enrolment. Both activities were cost-effective, targeting the different audiences, leading to higher ROI.
Please explain Was the activity cost effective overall for each activity

For Marketing Activity 1: Social Media Campaign, the activity is cost-effective in the overall analysis since the campaign utilises low-cost social media platforms and influencer marketing, potentially providing a higher ROI. Also, measuring and evaluating the KPIs regularly will ensure a return on investment.

For Marketing Activity 2: Print Media Advertisements, the activity was cost-effective overall as it utilised low-cost print media platforms such as newspapers and brochures at local business events. The targeted local audience is also under the category of Career Training's target market, leading to a higher ROI. Measurement of the effectiveness through tracking enquiries generated and enrolment rates can give a clear picture of the activity's cost-effectiveness.
For the marketing activity 2 provide DETAIL WHAT THE MARKETING ACTIVITY WILL BE:

Marketing Activity 2: Print Media Advertisements

The marketing activity will involve publishing advertisements related to Career Training's Diploma in Business Administration course in various local newspapers, magazines, and brochures. The design and content of the advertisements will showcase the unique features and benefits of the course, along with the contact information of Career Training.

The objective of this marketing activity is to create awareness of the course in the local community, targeting potential students and parents looking for different career opportunities. By publishing in targeted publications such as local newspapers and magazines, it can gain significant attention at lower costs.

Another element of the marketing activity is distributing brochures at local business events such as job fairs, exhibitions, and seminars. The brochure will contain details of the Diploma in Business Administration course, along with other specialisations offered by Career Training. The brochure will be designed professionally, engaging, and provide valuable information to potential students and parents looking for career opportunities.

The cost of this activity will include the designing cost of the advertisements and brochures, the placement fees or cost for publishing the adverts in local newspapers and magazines, and distribution fees. 

The effectiveness of the activity can be measured by tracking the number of enquiries generated from the advertisements and brochures, the number of students enrolled in the course after the publication, and comparing the costs to the revenue generated.
or the marketing activity 2 open day provide DETAIL WHAT THE MARKETING ACTIVITY WILL BE:

I'm sorry, it seems there was an error in the original prompt as Marketing Activity 2 was listed as Print Media Advertisements. However, I can still provide a detailed response on Marketing Activity 2 as an Open Day event.

Marketing Activity 2: Open Day Event

The marketing activity will involve organising a Career Training Open Day Event to showcase the different courses offered by the organisation, focusing on Diploma in Business Administration, the featured course. The event will be held on Career Training premises and will be open to the public. 

The objective of this marketing activity is to create awareness of the Career Training Institute among the targeted audience, providing students with the opportunity to meet and speak with trainers and staff about the courses offered, and experience the facilities on offer. Various activities and interactive sessions will be organised throughout the day to provide a complete understanding of the courses and services available.

The cost of this activity will include the design cost of the event, catering, equipment hiring cost, promotions and advertising, and staff costs. 

The effectiveness of the activity can be measured by the number of visitors and students who attend the event, their level of engagement during the event, the number of enquiries generated, and the number of students enrolled in the course after the event. Lastly, comparing the cost of the event against the revenue generated from the new students enrolled can help identify the effectiveness of the open-day event.

按照 概论、洞察、创意张力、执行，这四个步骤，以简洁的方式写出以下内容案列分析。
标题：达美航空：世界是个万花筒，等你来打开

如果可以重新发现一个更丰富多彩的世界，为什么要满足于灰色世界？
近日，Delta Airlines（达美航空）发布了一支缤纷绚烂的60秒广告《The World is Your Kaleidoscope（世界是你的万花筒）》，旨在通过一个迷失在平凡生活中的女性的旅行，鼓励人们摆脱索然无味的生活，让旅行给他们的生活增添色彩。
短片拥有极具视觉冲击的色调，搭配创意转场的艺术表现手法，不失为一场美轮美奂的视觉盛宴。同时以EGOT（美国艺术四大奖项）冠军Viola Davis（维奥拉·戴维斯）的标志性声音为旁白，更添了几分艺术气息。
一个处于灰色世界中的女人，在人群中看到一架达美飞机经过，心中若有所思。
随后镜头转向达美登机口，她向那个彩色的门走去，开启了一场“彩色的”旅行，体验世界的丰富多彩。
随着视频接近尾声，留下了发人深省的文字：只要睁开眼睛，就能打开你的世界。简而言之，是时候走出去探索了！

概论：
本案例分析旨在探讨达美航空推出的一支广告短片，通过绚丽的画面和丰富的视觉表现，鼓励人们走出日常生活，去发现更为丰富多彩的世界。

洞察：
广告从对个体生活无聊和对美好世界的向往两个方面出发，描述了一个迷失在平凡生活中的女性如何通过旅行重新找回生活的色彩。

创意张力：
广告通过与现实生活形成鲜明对比的方式，运用极具视觉冲击的色调和创意转场技巧，展示了旅行带给人们生活的美丽变化。

执行：
广告以维奥拉·戴维斯的声音为背景，通过女主角从灰色世界走向达美航空登机口，开启彩色之旅的故事情节，传递出走出去探索的核心信息。

按照 概论、洞察、创意张力、执行，这四个步骤，以简洁的方式写出以下内容案列分析。
标题：饿了么《清明·百味青团》：青团打起来啦！

清明节来临之际，饿了么拍摄了一支脑洞大开的广告片《清明·百味青团》，饿了么小哥穿越古今，见证了一场青团新旧口味之战，豆沙和蛋黄，你pick哪个？

概论：
本案例分析旨在探讨饿了么在清明节期间推出的一支别出心裁的广告片《清明·百味青团》，以展现广告中的古今穿越、新旧口味之战的创意，引发观众对清明节美食青团的思考和兴趣。

洞察：
广告结合了清明节民俗氛围和现代人对于传统食物口味的不同需求，通过创意的故事情节展现了古今对比、经典与创新的呈现。

创意张力：
广告通过饿了么小哥穿越古今，置身于一场脑洞大开的青团口味大战，将观众带入了有趣的文化碰撞，增强了广告的吸引力。

执行：
广告在场景设计、角色设定以及呈现效果上，成功呈现出古今穿越与口味之战的趣味性，强化了节日氛围和美食关注度，推动观众进行美食选择和消费。

conversation.content: Marketing is a business function that focuses on identifying, building, and sustaining relationships with target audiences to create and maintain interest in a company's products or services. This includes research and analysis, advertising, promotion and communication strategies. Meanwhile, advertising is a subset of marketing that involves utilizing various platforms and mediums, such as print, television, radio, online, billboards, or social media, to create and share messages with a target audience. Advertising aims to increase brand awareness, promote products or services, and generate sales or leads.

Este texto consta de diversas sugerencias y estrategias para mejorar las ventas en línea y ganar más dinero. A continuación se resumen los puntos más importantes:

- Obtener los mejores precios y productos para la venta.
- Crear una estrategia de marketing para promocionar los productos y atraer a más clientes.
- Explorar la posibilidad de ampliar el alcance vendiendo en plataformas adicionales.
- Proporcionar una excelente atención al cliente para fidelizar a los clientes actuales y atraer a nuevos clientes.
- Realizar un seguimiento de las ventas y el inventario para asegurarse de que los productos más populares estén disponibles.
- Elegir la plataforma de venta en línea que mejor se adapte a tus productos y necesidades.
- Optimizar tus listados de productos para cada plataforma, siguiendo las pautas y directrices de cada una.
- Explorar la posibilidad de ofrecer envío gratuito o descuentos en envío para incentivar a los compradores a realizar compras.
- Buscar maneras de diferenciarte de otros vendedores en línea, por ejemplo, ofreciendo productos únicos o personalizados.
- Considerar la posibilidad de anunciar tus productos en sitios web y foros relacionados con tus productos o nicho de mercado.
- Analizar las tendencias de ventas y ajustar el inventario en consecuencia.
- Implementar un sistema de seguimiento de inventario en tiempo real para poder realizar ajustes rápidos en caso de necesidad.
- Investigar y utilizar herramientas de gestión de inventario para optimizar el proceso.
- Explorar la posibilidad de establecer alianzas estratégicas con proveedores para asegurar el suministro constante de los productos más populares.
- Realizar proyecciones de ventas y ajustar el inventario en consecuencia para poder maximizar las ganancias.
- Realizar un seguimiento regular de las ventas y ajustar los precios o promociones en consecuencia.
- Explorar la posibilidad de ampliar la variedad de productos ofrecidos para atraer a más clientes.
- Establecer alianzas con influencers o bloggers para promocionar tus productos en sus redes sociales.
- Optimizar tus listados de productos con palabras clave relevantes para aumentar la visibilidad en los motores de búsqueda.
- Investigar y utilizar herramientas de análisis de datos para obtener información sobre el comportamiento de compra de tus clientes y ajustar tu estrategia en consecuencia.
- Ofrecer servicios de tutoría presencial y en línea para estudiantes de su zona.
- Crear un programa de afiliados para incentivar a otros tutores a trabajar contigo y aumentar tus ganancias.
- Investigar y ofrecer servicios de tutoría en áreas de alta demanda como matemáticas, ciencias y examenes de ingreso a universidades.
- Ofrecer un paquete de tutorías a un precio competitivo para atraer a clientes que necesitan una cantidad significativa de horas de tutoría.
- Crear una página web para promocionar tus servicios y llegar a un público más amplio.
- Realizar un seguimiento de tus ingresos y gastos para asegurarte de que estás maximizando tus ganancias.
- Ofrecer tutorías en múltiples idiomas para atraer a clientes internacionales.
- Investigar y comparar los precios y la calidad de los proveedores para obtener los mejores precios y productos para la venta.
- Agregar más productos artesanales de alta calidad a tu tienda en Etsy.
- Ofrecer servicios de asesoramiento financiero o contable a pequeñas empresas o emprendedores para generar ingresos adicionales y acercarse al objetivo de ganar 100 euros al día.
- Explorar la posibilidad de colaborar con otros vendedores en línea para aumentar el alcance de las promociones y llegar a más clientes.

- Explorar la posibilidad de ofrecer servicios de consultoría en línea en áreas de tu experiencia para generar ingresos adicionales y acercarse al objetivo de ganar 100 euros al día.

conversations.facetValue: analyze a case study on Volkswagen India's digital marketing strategy and provide a detailed case analysis following a structured framework.

allFacetValues.value: analyze Volkswagen's digital marketing strategy, critique the campaigns, and suggest future strategies for the company.
English
analyze a case study on Volkswagen India's digital marketing strategy and provide a detailed case analysis following a structured framework.

conversation.content:
You will be turning in a written report for this assignment.
Examine the case: 1) Analyze Volkswagen's digital marketing strategy and critique the campaigns and 2) Suggest a digital marketing strategy for Volkswagen in the future by providing rationales.
Case: Volkswagen India: Das Auto Digitally by Seema Gupta. Published - May 1, 2015
How to analyze a case:
The case analysis framework presented here is a synthesis of the frameworks used by your
professor and other marketing professors who use case analysis in their courses. It will provide a
solid structure to organize the diverse information presented in a case.
As you work your way through this framework, or a similar approach to case analysis, we offer
the following hints to increase your probability of success:
1. No one can analyze a case after reading it only one time, or even worse, doing the analysis
during the first reading of the case. You should read through the case once just to get an
understanding of the nature of the case. During the second reading, you can begin to structure
and classify the issues as they appear. A truly comprehensive case analysis will probably
require at least three readings.
2. Don’t get trapped into thinking the “answer” to the case is hidden somewhere in the case text.
There is never a single answer to a case just as there is never a single marketing strategy that
is appropriate for all situations. Each case is unique. Looking for tricks or shortcuts is not
appropriate.
3. Make an effort to put yourself in the shoes of the decision maker in the case. The use of role-
playing as part of the analysis can be very useful. It helps you gain some feeling for the
perspective of the key parties at the time the case took place. After you have done several
analyses, you will likely come up with your own additional procedures or guidelines that
assist you with this process.
Step 1: Situation Analysis
The material presented in a case is much like the communications we have in our daily lives.
Usually our conversations involve the selection of a topic and then the discussion of that topic,
and so it is with cases. The problem is that we end up with bits and pieces of information that by
themselves are not very useful, but once organized, can be quite valuable in our assessment of the
situation. The first step in the framework helps you organize the pieces of information into more
useful topic blocks.
The process of assessing a situation is widely accomplished through the use of SWOT Analysis
(strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats). Looking at an organization’s strengths and
weaknesses is the first half of Step 1. This involves looking at the organization’s internal
environment. Strengths are those aspects of the internal environment that can help the firm
address a present problem, issue, or opportunity, while weaknesses are negative factors or
deficiencies that do not allow the firm to reach its full potential. One topic that should be
addressed is the content and appropriateness of the current marketing or sales plan. Is the plan
current? Do the key parties understand and utilize it? Was it developed with input from all levels
of the organization? The organization’s financial condition may also present strengths and
weaknesses. Is it in a solid position, and does it have, or can it acquire, needed funds at a
reasonable cost of capital? Other possible strengths and weaknesses might include managerial
expertise, human resources, product reputation and customer loyalty, patents and trademarks, age
and capacity of production facilities, channel relationships, and promotional programs (sales
force, advertising program, publicity, and sales promotion efforts). These are all issues that we
want to consider in terms of both the present state of the firm and identifiable trends.
Students assessing a case situation see the importance of considering the organization’s internal
environment fairly naturally. The aspect of SWOT analysis that gives students the most difficulty
is the external environment where all opportunities and threats reside. These are issues that exist
outside the boundaries of the firm. All opportunities and threats will exist at their present levels
even if the organization in question does not exist. Technology, competition, the macroeconomic
environment, regulation, and social and cultural trends are all issues that affect the success of an
organization’s strategies, but the organization has only limited influence on them.
Because the power to affect the external environment significantly is usually absent, management
must view the factors and forces present in the external environment as issues to be considered,
but not usually controlled. Managers should take steps to minimize the exposure to threats and to
take full advantage of the opportunities. You might think of opportunities and threats as currents
in a river. It is much easier to find a river whose currents will help take you where you are going
than to try to make headway going against the force of the river.
You may get hung up on several points when conducting a SWOT analysis. First, while a factor
will usually fall into only one of the four categories, this is not always the case. A factor can be
both a strength and a weakness, or an opportunity and a threat. For example, excess capacity in a
factory would be a weakness from a production efficiency standpoint. But, it could be a strength
if the firm is looking to introduce a new product because it will not have to build a new factory.
The second and more serious issue is the difficulty in identifying opportunities. There is a
tendency to confuse opportunities with possibilities. Something the company might do, such as
franchise its operations in an effort to expand, is not an opportunity. The mention of the
organization’s name in the opportunity is a clear indication that it is not an issue from the
external environment. Both threats and opportunities would be present even if the organization
did not exist.
Finally, you are accustomed to the material in a textbook containing accurate information that
should be believed and remembered. However, in some cases, you will find statements of
opinion that are often biased by a person’s motives and position in a firm. The organization’s
CEO who has just recently given approval to the firm’s strategic plan might say, “This is an
excellent mission statement that will effectively direct our firm’s efforts for the next decade.” Is
this really true? It might be, but it will be up to you to determine what is fact as opposed to
someone’s opinion. Opinions will need to be assessed in your case analysis to determine their
accuracy.
Step 2: Assumptions and Missing Information
As with life, it is neither possible nor realistic for cases to contain all the information a decision
maker might wish to have available. Usually a decision maker has only bits and pieces of
information. He or she must either fill in the gaps, or make the decision that the information is
not critical, fairly predictable, or simply too costly and time-consuming to justify collecting for
the decision at hand. A marketing manager might want to know the history of competitive
reactions to price cuts by his firm. This information may be present in company files. It also
might be available from trade sources or other noncompetitive channel members.
In step two you will list important information not contained in the case, why that information
might be useful, and how you might go about acquiring it. This is more than just a wish list. The
items included here should considered thoroughly. The list should contain pieces of information
that would help shore up or fill gaps in your SWOT analysis.
Some of the information that is not available can be addressed through assumptions. One might
assume that if information about the firm’s advertising budget is not available, it would be equal
to industry averages. The same assumptions might be made for other costs and revenues. It is
critical that these assumptions be realistic and clearly identified before and during the case
analysis. This list should contain only those items that will be truly useful in enhancing the
quality of the decisions made. It should not be a list of things that would be interesting to know.
The quality of your analysis will depend on your coverage of the framework, the depth of your
analysis, and the degree to which you can defend your recommendations.
Step 3: Problem Definition
The identification and clear presentation of the problem(s) or issue(s) facing the company is the
most critical part of the analysis framework. Only a problem properly defined can be addressed.
Define the problem too narrowly, or miss the key problem all together, and all subsequent
framework steps will be off the mark. Getting a clear picture of the problem is one major benefit
derived from SWOT analysis.
The process of identifying problems is similar to the one people go through with their doctors. A
nurse or assistant comes in to conduct a strength and weakness assessment on you. Your vital
signs are taken and you are asked about any symptoms you may be experiencing. Symptoms are
observable manifestations or indications that a problem may be present. Symptoms are not the
problem themselves. If you have a temperature of 103 degrees, that is a symptom. If the medical
staff were to pack you in ice for several minutes, that reading would probably approach 98.6
degrees. Would that make you well? It might make your condition worse! The doctor uses the
information collected from you, with knowledge of the viruses and diseases that are present in
the external environment, to identify what has led to your high fever. The doctor will attempt to
diagnose the real problem, then prescribe treatment from a set of feasible alternatives (make
recommendations about what steps will help solve the problem) and provide you with a
prognosis (an indication of the things you can expect to occur as you are recovering).
The case analysis process is similar to the doctor’s analysis and treatment of a patient in several
basic ways. First, symptoms are the most observable indication that a problem exists. Many
students are very quick to start treating the symptoms found in a case, as opposed to digging
deeper to find the underlying problem(s). A symptom may be that sales are down from previous
periods. If this is how you define the problem, your answer might be to cut the price. This might
be an appropriate step, but not based on the analysis to this point. Sales might pick up, but will
this reaction make the company healthier? This is a clear case of prescription without adequate
diagnosis.
The most important question in the identification of any problem is “Why?” The Why question
should always be asked after a potential problem has been proposed. To illustrate, pinpointing
the problem associated with the sales decline in our previous example might progress like this:
The problem is that sales have declined.
Why have sales declined?
Sales have declined because there are too many sales territories that are not
assigned to a salesperson.
Why are so many sales territories unassigned?
Sales territories are unassigned because sales force turnover has
doubled in the past year.
Why has sales force turnover doubled?
Turnover began to increase over a year ago when
the sales force compensation plan was altered in
order to reduced variable expenses.
When you can no longer devise a meaningful response to the Why? question, you have probably
found the problem. In this instance, the problem statement might read:
The current sales force compensation plan at XYZ Company is inadequate to retain an
acceptable percentage of the firm’s salespeople, resulting in lost customers and decreased
sales.
The problem statement should be brief—almost always one or two sentences. It should be to the
point, and it should provide a clear indication as to what must be addressed to improve the
performance of the organization.
Given this problem statement, our first reaction, to work on the symptom of reduced sales by
cutting prices, would clearly not solve the problem. When we work on symptoms, the symptom
may go away, but the problem will always manifest itself again with the same symptom, or a
related one. Cutting prices would enhance sales, but would it be profitable? And, with an
understaffed sales force, could the firm serve customers at a level that would keep them
satisfied?
Step 4: Development of Alternatives
Once we have the problem clearly and succinctly defined, we are in a position to develop a set of
strategic alternatives that have a reasonable potential to solve the problem. A key problem
students face in this step is that they generate a laundry list of a dozen fairly detail-oriented items.
These items have a lot more to do with the tactics of implementing a strategy than with
presenting alternative strategies from which we will make our selections. Going back to the sales
force example above, the list may include ideas such as:
 Take candidates through a more rigorous interview process
 Lengthen the training program
 Give every salesperson a company car
 Offer both individual and regional bonuses
 Increase company contribution to the retirement program for each year of employment
 Conduct an employee-evaluation training program for the firm’s sales managers
While these may all be good ideas, they are not strategic alternatives. The term alternative
suggests an either/or situation. From the list above, you might include several items in your
recommendation section. Strategic alternatives should identify basic directions the firm might go
with the sales force support of its product.
One alternative is always the status quo. You must understand that this is not a means of
avoiding a decision. If recommended as the next step, it is a conscious decision, based on a
careful evaluation, that the present strategy in use, perhaps with some tactical modifications, is
the best course of action in the current situation.
Besides the status quo, you should use creative thinking to come up with several truly strategic
alternatives. For our present example, one option might be to eliminate the external sales force
and start using a manufacturer’s representative network to sell to the firm’s customers. Another
alternative would be to use direct marketing, with an inside sales force to market the product.
Another possible option is to reemphasize the sales force with a more effective sales
management program, including better selection, compensation, evaluation, and recognition of
the sales force.
Frequently, the underlying problem facing the organization is the failure to have a current, widely
used, well-developed marketing plan. If the analysis indicates this to be the case, conducting a
comprehensive strategic market planning process should be one of the alternatives listed. This is
one of the few options that might be selected in combination with some other alternative.
Step 5: Evaluation of Alternatives & Recommendations
Once you have developed a set of realistic alternatives, it is time to do a thorough evaluation of
each of the options. Three major criteria should be used in this evaluation process. First, how
well does the alternative address the problem or issue as stated in Step 3? Closely related to the
first criterion is the consistency of the alternative with the organization’s mission, as well as its
ability to assist in achieving the plan’s stated goals and objectives. Clearly, for an organization
whose mission includes providing the most innovative health care products to doctors, nurses,
and patients, a low cost/price competitive organization model would be inappropriate.
This does not mean alternatives that are not consistent with the present plan should never be
selected. It does indicate that part of the evaluation for such alternatives must address the
complete modification of the organization’s strategic plan. Likewise, an objective of increasing
profit margins from 15% to 25% is not consistent with the alternative of becoming a low-price
provider. The deletion, or at the very least modification, of this aspect of the plan must be
considered in evaluating this alternative.
For each alternative, you should make an effort to estimate and evaluate the cost and revenue
implications of the option. Probable income statements, under corresponding stated assumptions,
should be included for each alternative. Exhibit 1 provides an example of just such an
assessment. Costs are certainly easier to calculate than revenue projections, but an effort must be
made to do both. To conclude simply that developing a new innovative product line for the
organization, without any discussion of the costs and benefits involved, or in what year each is
likely to occur, is an incomplete and unrealistic approach to case analysis. You should use what
you have learned from your accounting and finance courses when you conduct case analyses.
Look at any financial information you are given in the case, or that you can acquire, as a key
resource in conducting your analysis.
<Insert Exhibit 1 Here (see end of file)>
The final criterion is an important one that relates to the feasibility and probable success of each
alternative: How well do the alternatives coincide with the key findings from the SWOT Analysis
you conducted in Step 1? In other words, how well does each alternative match up with the
internal and external environments of the organization? Does the organization have, or can it
realistically acquire, the human and financial resources required by each alternative? Building
additional capacity to increase volume as the low-price provider is probably not a reasonable
alternative for an organization in great financial difficulty. Conversely, for a firm with limited
history and investment in research and development, becoming the innovative leader in the
industry will not be possible in the near term.
The external environment, in terms of the economy, competition, regulation, and cultural trends,
will have a major impact on the pro forma revenue projections you make in this step. Any
alternative that adds pollution to the environment will not be well received today. Often,
alternative analyses assume the competition is an inanimate object. Thinking that competitors
will stand still while you steal their customers with a new marketing strategy is not at all realistic.
Part of the evaluation of alternatives, and making projections about their potential success, is to
use the assessment of the external environment to make assumptions about what key competitors
will do. You must remember that as one company is setting a course for the future, most of its
effective competitors are doing likewise.
The recommendation portion of this step is often included as a separate phase in the case analysis
framework. We include evaluation with recommendation because, if the former is done well, the
latter should be a natural continuation of the process. The alternative chosen is the one that
stands up best in terms of all three criteria: consistency with mission, goals and objectives as
stated or as modified, strongest probable financial performance, and harmony with the internal
and external environments of the organization. With a thorough evaluation, the recommended
alternative should be a natural move. This does not mean that two alternatives will never be close
in terms of their attractiveness, but usually one will be a better match for the organization as a
whole.
One more note: Become accustomed to making recommendations in the face of unknown
economic or competitive conditions. While you will be able to know some things for certain
(such as gross domestic product or consumer spending), no one can possibly predict all future
events. As long as your evaluation is thorough, and your assumptions are clearly stated and reasonable, your recommendations will be justified.

Start with a background, approximately 1 page in length. Describe the pertinent history of the organization, including its mission and vision, goals and objectives, and strategies. Include only those points which affect the current situation, possible alternatives, or future performance of the company. 

Example background (in an analysis of apple pay):
Apple Pay is a mobile application service developed by the technology company, Apple.
The service allows users to make payments with mobile phones inside the iOS operating system.
It was launched on September 9, 2014, under the leadership of Tim Cook. Apple Pay's vision is
to replace the physical wallet. This vision contributes to Apple's overall mission: to bring the
best user experience to customers with its products. The goal of Apple Pay is to transform the
mobile payment industry. Making the checkout process easier for online purchases allows users
to experience convenience, save time, and reduce effort with the payment platform. Targeting
shoppers with Apple devices was a marketing strategy to gain early adoption. Banks, major
credit card companies, and retailers had a partnership with Apple to introduce Apple Pay to
consumers. However, in the early stages, the mobile application service would face problems.
Other mobile services before Apple Pay had adoption failure. Transaction errors caused missed
opportunities. Not all places of commerce accepted the payment service.

Background

Volkswagen India, a subsidiary of the German parent company Volkswagen Group, was founded in 2007 and started its operations in 2009 as the Indian automobile market was growing rapidly. The company's vision was to become the most innovative high-volume automaker in the market, offering environment-friendly and value-rich products. With a mission to become a leading player in the Indian automobile market and to make India a key hub for manufacturing vehicles, Volkswagen India adopted the brand philosophy of "Innovation, Sophistication, and Responsibility." The company implemented a multi-brand strategy, aggressively marketing its range of vehicles in India.

Volkswagen India's marketing strategy has primarily focused on creating awareness and generating interest through innovative communication campaigns. The company has consistently leveraged digital marketing channels for their campaigns, including social media, email marketing, search engine marketing, and online advertising. Some of the prominent digital marketing campaigns include the "Anything4Jetta" campaign, which used social media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube to promote the Jetta launch, and the "Vento Project," an online platform that encouraged customers to co-create a Vento model. In addition, Volkswagen India has utilized digital technologies to engage with customers and enhance the overall customer experience.

However, the automobile industry in India is highly competitive with numerous domestic and international players, and Volkswagen India faces stiff competition from market leaders such as Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, Honda, and Tata Motors. As a result, Volkswagen India finds itself in a challenging position, requiring continuous innovation in its digital marketing strategy to stay ahead of the competition and maintain its position as a leading player in the market.

Analysis & Critique of Volkswagen India's Digital Marketing Strategy

Volkswagen India's digital marketing strategy has been innovative and aggressive, leveraging the power of digital platforms to target a wide range of customers effectively. The company has used digital channels to engage customers during the pre-launch, launch, and post-launch phases of new vehicle models, creating buzz and generating interest through creative digital campaigns.

One of the strengths of Volkswagen India's digital marketing strategy is its focus on engaging users and encouraging them to actively participate in the campaigns. For example, the "Anything4Jetta" campaign involved users sharing stories, images, and videos demonstrating the lengths they would go to own a Jetta. By utilizing user-generated content and making customers an active part of the campaign, Volkswagen India was able to create a personal connection and a sense of loyalty among its target audience.

However, Volkswagen's digital marketing campaigns have also faced certain challenges and weaknesses. For instance, the "Vento Project" campaign received criticism for plagiarizing the contents of a popular car show. This tarnished Volkswagen's image and hurt the brand's credibility. Additionally, the company has not fully utilized the potential of emerging digital marketing channels like chatbots and influencer marketing, which could enhance customer engagement and brand visibility.

Suggested Digital Marketing Strategy for Volkswagen India

To stay ahead of the competition and maintain its position in the Indian automobile market, Volkswagen India should consider implementing the following digital marketing strategies:

1. Enhance and personalize the customer experience: Volkswagen India should focus on using data analytics and artificial intelligence to gain deeper insights into customer preferences and behavior. This would enable the company to create personalized digital marketing campaigns and tailor content to meet the specific needs of individual customers, resulting in higher customer satisfaction and loyalty.

2. Utilize emerging digital marketing channels: As mentioned earlier, Volkswagen India has not fully leveraged the potential of emerging digital marketing channels like chatbots and influencer marketing. Embracing these channels can help the company reach a larger audience, increase brand visibility, and engage customers on a deeper level.

3. Focus on online reputation management: Given the previous instances of negative publicity, Volkswagen India needs to prioritize managing its online reputation to ensure that customers perceive the brand positively. Engaging with customers through social listening, addressing customer concerns promptly, and regularly monitoring and responding to online reviews can help the company maintain a strong online presence and improve customer trust.

4. Collaborate with digital marketing partners: Partnering with digital marketing agencies or technology companies can help Volkswagen India expand its digital marketing capabilities and stay ahead of the competition. This collaboration could involve utilizing cutting-edge technologies, leveraging industry expertise, and accessing a wider pool of creative resources for developing unique and compelling digital campaigns.

5. Focus on measuring the effectiveness of digital campaigns: Lastly, Volkswagen India should invest in tracking and analyzing the performance of its digital marketing campaigns to determine their success and identify areas for improvement. This would involve setting specific, measurable goals for each campaign and using relevant metrics like conversion rates, click-through rates, and ROI to assess campaign performance. This data-driven approach can help the company refine its digital marketing strategy and make data-backed decisions to achieve optimal results.

Volkswagen India is a subsidiary of the renowned German automaker, Volkswagen Group, which entered the Indian automotive market in 2007 and commenced operations in 2009. With an optimistic vision of becoming the most innovative high-volume automaker, Volkswagen India aimed to deliver value-rich and environment-friendly products to the rapidly growing Indian market. The company's mission was to establish itself as a leading player in the Indian automobile industry, turning India into a key manufacturing hub for its vehicles while embracing the brand philosophy of "Innovation, Sophistication, and Responsibility."

To penetrate the competitive Indian market and create a strong brand presence, Volkswagen India employed a multi-brand strategy that involved aggressively marketing its diverse portfolio of vehicles. At the core of the company's marketing strategy was the crucial focus on building brand awareness and sustaining consumer interest through innovative communication campaigns employing digital marketing channels. Volkswagen India concentrated its marketing efforts on platforms such as social media, email marketing, and online advertising, establishing a connect with customers and prospects in the pre-launch, launch, and post-launch phases of its vehicles.

Some notable digital marketing campaigns orchestrated by the company include the "Anything4Jetta" campaign, which utilized Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube to generate buzz around the Jetta launch. Another innovative effort, the "Vento Project," provided an online platform enabling customers to co-create a Vento model, thereby promoting customer engagement and product personalization.

Despite Volkswagen India's relative success in incorporating digital marketing strategies, the Indian automobile industry remained fiercely competitive, with major domestic and global brands such as Maruti Suzuki, Hyundai, Honda, and Tata Motors vying for market dominance. Consequently, Volkswagen India found itself confronted with the continuous challenge of innovating its digital marketing strategies to maintain a leading position in the market and anticipate the evolving preferences and trends of the Indian consumer.

Apple is an established, reliable brand. The company was founded by Steve Wozniak and
Steve Jobs in 1976. As a personal computer manufacturer, the firm competed with the top firms in
the computing industry, such as IBM and Hewlett-Packard. Apple has created great computers and
has impacted the technology world. The firm was successful with the release of the Apple II and
other Macintosh products. The brand is known for its customer loyalty, customer satisfaction, and
high-end products (Forsido, 2012).
Innovation is a critical success factor for Apple. During the early 2000s, after Steve Jobs
return to the company, it made a crucial pivot. The firm entered the smartphone market by
introducing the iPhone. Having all the products integrated under one operating system has caused
people to fall in love with the user experience. For consecutive years, Apple is known as the most
innovative company in the world.
Massive global sales of hardware and software have contributed to the strong market cap.
Apple has a significant market share of phone sales. The application store, iTunes, is a success for
app sales, outdoing the Android application market. Apple has a market cap of $1.3 trillion (Mickle
& Ramkumar, 2018).
The firm has several weaknesses. Apple is known for having expensive products. The price
is double, sometimes quadruple the price of competitors’ products with similar specifications.
Apple rarely has sales on their products. Also, their products do not play well with other third-
party products. Apple likes to keep everything in-house from app purchases to software services.
No product or service is open-source. By locking down the Apple ecosystem, the company knows
it can get away with limited promotion. Product releases are kept a secret, and not much
information is known about future features and benefits.

Consistent customer growth and increased mobile device usage are opportunities for Apple
to advance as a business. The mission statement is what causes users to keep coming back to iOS
devices. The user experience is incredible, and more people are switching to Apple products for
the hardware quality and ease of use. The company has a 92 percent retention rate (Gottsegen,
2017). People are receiving information from smartphones and tablets. Handheld computers are
the future of technology, and innovating in this space will spark people to buy iOS devices.
Threats of payment service competitors and alternative payment methods will keep Apple’s
leadership awake at night. Google has released Android Pay to compete with Apple and entice
users to switch from iOS to Android. Banks, retailers, and other phone manufacturers are releasing
digital wallets. With more digital wallets, there are more digital currencies being released.
Cryptocurrencies could become a new payment method for online purchases.

Situation Analysis

Strengths
1. Established brand: Volkswagen enjoys a strong position as one of the leading automotive brands in the world, renowned for its German engineering, reliability, and quality.
2. Diverse product portfolio: Volkswagen India offers a wide range of products catering to various segments, including hatchbacks, sedans, and SUVs, appealing to different customers.
3. Strong global presence: As a part of the Volkswagen Group, Volkswagen India benefits from the Group's extensive global network, technology sharing, and synergies.
4. Innovative digital marketing campaigns: Volkswagen India has been successful in creating impactful digital marketing campaigns, effectively engaging customers and fostering brand loyalty.

Weaknesses
1. Market penetration: Despite being a renowned brand, Volkswagen India has a relatively low market share compared to some of its competitors in the Indian automotive market.
2. Pricing strategy: Volkswagen's vehicles tend to be priced higher than the competitors, which may limit the brand's appeal to the price-sensitive Indian market.
3. Service network: Compared to some established players in the industry, Volkswagen India's service network and after-sales support may be limited in some regions, influencing the customer's purchase decisions.
4. Sustainability issues: The 2015 dieselgate scandal involving emission cheating by Volkswagen has negatively impacted the brand's reputation globally and may hinder consumer trust.

Opportunities
1. Growing demand for SUVs & electric vehicles: Responding to the increasing popularity of SUVs and the growing interest in electric vehicles in India, Volkswagen can expand its product portfolio to capture these emerging market trends.
2. Digitalization in the automotive industry: Volkswagen India can capitalize on the expanding digital landscape to enhance customer experience and engagement, leveraging new tools like augmented reality, virtual showrooms, and artificial intelligence for its digital marketing campaigns.
3. Government initiatives: The Indian government's push for electric mobility and clean energy provides Volkswagen India with an opportunity to collaborate on electric vehicle infrastructure development and launch electric vehicles that cater to the Indian market.

Threats
1. Intense competition: The Indian automobile industry is highly competitive and fragmented, with numerous domestic and international players vying for market share. Maintaining a competitive edge in this market becomes increasingly challenging.
2. Price sensitivity: The Indian market is highly price-sensitive, with consumers seeking value and affordability. Volkswagen's premium pricing strategy may limit its market penetration in this environment.
3. Regulatory changes and policy interventions: Changes in government regulations and policies related to emission norms, safety norms, and taxation may affect the business operations and profitability of Volkswagen India.
4. Economic fluctuations: Fluctuations in macroeconomic factors like fuel prices, interest rates, and currency exchange rates can impact the consumer's buying behavior, thereby affecting Volkswagen India's sales performance.

Industry's Critical Success Factors
1. Product innovation: The ability to develop and launch new, innovative vehicles that cater to evolving customer preferences is a critical success factor within the highly competitive automotive industry.
2. Brand reputation: Establishing and maintaining a solid brand reputation based on quality, reliability, and consumer trust is essential for sustaining success in the automotive market.
3. Pricing strategy: Adopting a pricing strategy that balances product value and affordability is critical for capturing the price-sensitive Indian market.
4. Distribution & service network: A strong distribution network and after-sales support system are crucial for long-term growth and customer retention in the industry.
5. Marketing & customer engagement: Effectively leveraging digital and traditional marketing channels to create awareness, generate interest, and foster customer loyalty is vital in the automotive industry.
6. Environmental sustainability & compliance: With increasing focus on environment-friendly technologies and stricter regulations, complying with emission norms and investing in sustainable solutions is essential for success in the automotive sector.

Recommendation:

A combination of alternatives one, two, and three would be a suitable recommendation for Volkswagen India:

1. Expanding product portfolio: Volkswagen India should consider expanding its product portfolio to cater to the increasing demand for SUVs and electric vehicles in the Indian market. Diversifying its offerings will enable the company to adapt to market trends and cater to a diverse customer base while benefiting from government support for electric vehicle adoption. However, the company should be mindful of the development costs, intense competition, and the need to establish a charging infrastructure for electric vehicles.

2. Adopting competitive pricing strategy: To penetrate deeper into the price-sensitive Indian market, Volkswagen India should consider adopting a competitive pricing strategy without compromising the quality of its products. This could potentially widen the customer base, increase market penetration, and generate higher sales volumes. However, the company should be cautious of possible reduced profit margins and the potential impact on its brand image.

3. Strengthening distribution & service network: Increasing Volkswagen India's dealership and service network will improve the company's reach, enhance customer satisfaction, and provide better after-sales support. Investing in an extensive distribution and service network may seem time-consuming and involve increased operational costs. However, it will eventually pay off in terms of long-term growth and customer retention.

By implementing this combination of strategies, Volkswagen India can not only maintain its position as a leading player in the Indian automotive market but also successfully tackle the prevailing competition and the dynamism of consumer preferences.

4.1. The Black-Scholes Model: Assumptions and Intuition

  4.1.1. Overview of the Black-Scholes Model
      - Purpose of the model: Options pricing
      - Status as a cornerstone of modern financial theory
      
  4.1.2. Foundational Assumptions of the Black-Scholes Model
      - European-style options
      - No arbitrage opportunities
      - Efficient and frictionless markets
          - No transaction costs
          - No taxes
      - Constant and known interest rate, r
      - Constant and known volatility, σ
      - Log-normal distribution of stock price changes
      - Continuous price movements
      - No early exercise

  4.1.3. The Intuition Behind the Black-Scholes Model
      - Concept of risk-neutral pricing
      - The replicating portfolio strategy
          - Formation of a delta-hedged portfolio
          - Dynamic adjustment to maintain delta neutrality
      - The concept of self-financing portfolio
      - The role of Brownian motion in modeling stock prices
      - Connecting option prices to the expected payout
      - Pricing via discounting of expected future payoffs
      
  4.1.4. Comparing the Black-Scholes Model to Other Pricing Models
      - Binomial option pricing model
      - Monte Carlo simulations
      - Finite difference methods
      - Advantages and disadvantages of each method

  4.1.5. Practical Considerations in Using the Black-Scholes Model
      - Understanding the implications of the model's assumptions
      - Choosing the right inputs for the model
          - Historical vs. implied volatility
          - Estimating dividends and interest rates
      - Interpreting the results and making informed decisions
          - Sensitivity analysis: Greeks (Delta, Gamma, Theta, Vega, Rho)

4.4. Making Informed Marketing Decisions Using Attribution Models

In this section, we will discuss how to use the insights gained from Markov chain attribution models to make data-driven marketing decisions. Key topics will include:

   4.4.1. Interpreting Attribution Model Results
       - Understanding the roles of individual marketing channels
       - Analyzing channel transition probabilities
       - Identifying the most influential channels and touchpoints in the customer journey

   4.4.2. Informed Budget Allocation
       - Allocating your marketing budget based on channel influence
       - Balancing spending between top-performing and underutilized channels
       - Evaluating potential return on investment (ROI) for different marketing channels

   4.4.3. Optimizing Marketing Campaigns
       - Designing marketing campaigns that leverage high-performing channels
       - Refining targeting strategies based on attribution insights
       - Personalizing campaigns to increase channel effectiveness

   4.4.4. Enhancing Customer Experience and Retention
       - Understanding customer interactions across multiple channels
       - Identifying friction points that may lead to churn
       - Creating seamless and consistent experiences across touchpoints to improve customer retention
  
   4.4.5. Continuous Improvement and Monitoring
       - Regularly updating attribution models with new data
       - Conducting ongoing performance analysis to maintain awareness of changing trends
       - Utilizing A/B testing to validate marketing decisions derived from attribution models

By applying these insights, marketers will be better equipped to design and implement more effective strategies, allocate resources in a data-driven manner, and ultimately, increase the ROI of their marketing efforts.

conversations.facetValue: write a proposal for a sales and marketing team to launch and advertise a new organic snack product, Salted Fish Skin, in the Hong Kong market.

allFacetValues.value: write a proposal for a sales and marketing team to launch and advertise a new organic snack product, Salted Fish Skin, in Hong Kong.
English
write a proposal for a sales and marketing team to launch and advertise a new organic snack product, Salted Fish Skin, in the Hong Kong market.

conversation.content:
Topic
You and your group mates are the sales and marketing team of a medium-sized manufacturer of organic snacks based in Hong Kong – All About Natural Limited. Mr Timothy Jones, the General Manager of the company asked you to write a proposal to launch and advertise the company’s new product, Salted Fish Skin. 

“Salted Fish Skin” is the first healthy and organic crisp product manufactured by your company. Unlike all other crisps sold in Hong Kong, our product has three flavours of sweet and sour, spicy and original but they are low sugar, low calories, and the source of the fish skin is from organic farms in Hong Kong. In addition, the snacks are added with vitamin C which is good for health.  A colleague from your team, Jen Lee, has conducted a market survey on the organic snacks in Hong Kong and has submitted a report.

Read the report and write up the whole proposal. Remember to make up any relevant and necessary information on your own and make your own recommendations based on the report and your personal knowledge and experience. 
 

All About Natural Limited
Memorandum
To: Sales and Marketing Team
From: Jen Lee, sales and marketing assistant
Date: 21 March 2022
Subject: Report of the market survey on organic snacks – fish skin crisps in Hong Kong

1. Terms of Reference
I refer to your memo instructing me to carry out a market survey on the major fish skin sold in Hong Kong and submit herewith a brief report. I am now giving you the details about the survey conducted during March this year.

2. Methods
a. Questionnaire
A questionnaire was designed to obtain information about the favourite fish skin crisps of the teenagers and working adults in Hong Kong. 
b. Subjects
2500 teenagers and working adults responded to our questionnaire. Both genders of them were randomly picked on the street and came from different age groups – the youngest being 15 and the oldest being 38. 
c. Procedure
Six of our colleagues spent two weeks interviewing the subjects on the street outside the entrance of three MTR stations – Causeway Bay, Tsim Sha Tsui, and Tsuen Wan.

3. Findings
-  28% of the respondents have never tried fish skin crisps (organic or inorganic).
-  72% indicated that they tried different kinds of fish skin crisps:
33 % (Original Salted Egg Fish Skin from Irvins)
23% (Salted Egg Fish Skin from Golden Duck)
21% (Crispy Fish Skin with Chilli Sauce from Max Oceans)
13% (Salted Egg Fish Skin with Seaweed from Golden Duck)
10% (Others) 
The remaining 10% did not have a specific preference and like trying new tastes.

4. Conclusion
Hong Kong has a large market for fish skin. At present, it seems that fish skin with salted egg yolk has dominated the local market. Plus the imported brands from Singapore and Malaysia have triggered fierce competition with us.  Having said that, our Salted Fish Skin have the following strengths: 
    - the product has three flavours of sweet and sour, spicy and original but not made with egg yolk, 
    - they are low sugar, low calories, 
    - the source of the fish skin is from organic farms in Hong Kong, and
    - the snacks are rich in vitamin C which is good for health. 
According to our questionnaires, quite a number of respondents like trying new tastes and this can be our “competitive edge”. 

Guidelines
1. Create a sales and marketing team (a group of 3-4 people).
2. Write ONE proposal together to launch and advertise the company’s new product, Salted Fish Skin.
3. Only hard copy (typed) is accepted.
4. Deadline: Week 15. 
5. Word limit: four pages (Times New Roman, 12 points, A4 size – double line spacing)
6. Please take reference of “Example 3 Memo Proposal – A Proposal of Advertising Campaign” in your lecture notes.

All About Natural Limited
Proposal to Launch and Advertise Salted Fish Skin

1. Introduction

All About Natural Limited is a medium-sized manufacturer of organic snacks based in Hong Kong. We are well-known for our high-quality, innovative, and organic products, which cater to the increasing demand for healthier food alternatives in the market. In line with our mission and objectives, we hereby present a proposal to launch and advertise our new product – Salted Fish Skin.

2. Background

Based on a market survey conducted by our colleague Jen Lee, it was found that Hong Kong has a large market for fish skin, with 72% of the research respondents having tried different types of fish skin crisps. Currently, imported brands dominate the local market, with fish skin with salted egg yolk being the most popular flavor. Our new product – Salted Fish Skin – is unique in its taste and health benefits. With three flavors – sweet and sour, spicy, and original – it is made from low sugar, low calories recipes, and locally sourced organic fish skin. Additionally, it is rich in Vitamin C, making it a healthier option compared to existing products.

3. Objectives

The primary objectives of this proposal are to:

  a. Launch our new product, Salted Fish Skin, in the Hong Kong market.
  b. Create a strong brand presence and generate market awareness for the product.
  c. Establish a significant market share in the organic snack industry.
  d. Drive sales and achieve revenue targets.
  
4. Strategy

To achieve the objectives mentioned above, we propose the following strategies:

  a. Product Launch: Organize a launch event that brings together influencers, media, and potential customers to introduce the product and create a buzz in the market.

  b. Advertising: Utilize various advertising channels such as print media, social media, and outdoor advertising to reach our target audience, which includes teenagers and working adults between 15 and 38 years old.

  c. Promotions and Offers: Offer limited-time promotions and discounts to incentivize customers to try the product, and collaborate with popular retail outlets to improve product visibility.

  d. Public Relations: Engage in public relations activities, including press releases, media interviews, and partnership announcements to generate positive coverage and create a strong brand image.

  e. Influencer Marketing: Partner with popular food bloggers and influencers to promote our product and generate organic reviews and recommendations.

5. Implementation

The sales and marketing team will collaborate closely to ensure a seamless execution of the proposed strategies. The timeline for the implementation is as follows:

  a. 1st Month – Finalize product packaging, promotional materials, and event planning for the launch event.
  
  b. 2nd Month – Launch event, initiate advertising and promotional campaigns, and begin influencer marketing activities.
  
  c. 3rd Month – Evaluate the success of the launch, optimize marketing activities, and explore partnerships with retail outlets to extend product visibility.
  
  d. 4th to 6th Month – Maintain marketing and public relations efforts, assess progress, and make necessary adjustments to achieve objectives.

6. Budget

The proposed budget for the product launch and marketing activities:

  a. Product Launch Event: HKD 100,000
  b. Advertising (print, social media, and outdoor): HKD 300,000
  c. Promotions and Offers: HKD 50,000
  d. Public Relations: HKD 50,000
  e. Influencer Marketing: HKD 100,000
  f. Contingency (10% of the total budget): HKD 60,000
  TOTAL BUDGET: HKD 660,000

7. Conclusion

Salted Fish Skin has the potential to capture a significant share of the organic snack industry in Hong Kong, given its unique flavors and health benefits. Combining an effective marketing campaign with a strong product offering can significantly boost the product's popularity and lead to long-term success in the market. Therefore, we seek your approval for this proposal, as it will enable us to take the necessary steps to launch and advertise our new product, Salted Fish Skin, effectively in the local market.

Submitted by the Sales and Marketing Team:

1. (Name), Sales and Marketing Manager
2. (Name), Sales and Marketing Executive
3. (Name), Sales and Marketing Assistant
4. Jen Lee, Sales and Marketing Assistant
